journal-meta.journal-title: Proceedings of the Institution of Mechanical Engineers, Part O: Journal of Risk and Reliability

title-group.article-title: Optimum multi-objective modified constant-stress accelerated life test plan for the Burr type-XII distribution with type-I censoring

article-meta.aff: 1Department of Operational Research, University of Delhi, Delhi, India

author-notes.corresp: Preeti W Srivastava, Department of Operational Research, Faculty of Mathematical Sciences, University of Delhi, Delhi-7, Delhi 110007, India. Email: preetisrivastava.saxena@yahoo.co.in

abstract.p: Accelerated life test is usually performed using constant, step, progressive, cyclic and random stress loadings. In most of the existing accelerated life test plans, the stress level changes instantaneously, which is impractical. So, it is desirable to increase the stress at some finite rate, since a sudden jump in stress level may cause a thermal shock or undesirable failure modes that may not occur at the normal use condition. To overcome this problem, modified constant-stress loading and modified step-stress loading have been used in the literature in each of which stress is increased from a low stress level to higher stress level at a finite rate. This article deals with the design of an optimum multi-objective modified constant-stress accelerated life test plan for Burr type-XII distribution with type-I censoring. The inverse power law and a cumulative exposure model are assumed. The optimal test plan consists of determining an optimum low stress level, and also optimum proportion of units to be allocated at low and high stress levels by minimizing the weighted sum of the asymptotic variances of the maximum likelihood estimator of quantile lifetimes at design constant stress. The multi-objective modified constant-stress accelerated life test plan devised has been explained using a numerical example and the effects of the deviations from the pre-estimates of the design parameters investigated. The proposed model has been compared with the pre-existing model using the simulated failure time data set. For the same data set the proposed multi-objective plan has been compared with a single-objective plan with respect to changes in the values of the parameters, equal weights and unequal weights.

sec.title: Introduction and motivation
sec.p: Accelerated life test (ALT) is used to obtain information on the life of the products and materials in a shorter time. The experimental units are subject to stress conditions that are more severe than those encountered in normal use condition to induce early failures. The failure times observed under overstress conditions are analyzed in terms of a model and then extrapolated to estimate the life distribution at design stress. An optimal ALT plan helps in determining the optimum number of test units allocated at each stress level, optimum test duration and other experimental variables, and is designed to improve the accuracy of the reliability estimates.

ALT is usually performed using constant, step, progressive, cyclic and random (see Nelson1) stress loadings. But in this article modified constant-stress loading is used. In most of the existing ALT plans, the stress level changes instantaneously, which is impractical. So it is desirable to increase the stress at some finite rate, since a sudden jump in stress level may cause a thermal shock or undesirable failure modes, which may not occur at the normal use condition. In addition, it may not be desirable for some test units to jump instantaneously from a lower stress level to higher stress level. This has necessitated the use of modified constant-stress and modified step-stress loading in the literature. Further, it is impractical to estimate only one objective parameter after conducting costly ALT tests. Therefore, in this article, an optimum multi-objective modified constant-stress ALT plan has been designed. The need to analyze ALT data with different life distribution models such as exponential, normal, Weibull, log logistic, etc., is necessitated since the use of a correct life distribution model, especially in the presence of a limited source of a data (as typically occurs with modern devices, having high reliability) helps in preventing the choice of unnecessary and expensive planned replacements. The Burr type-XII life distribution used in this article has a non-monotone hazard function, which can accommodate many shapes of hazard function. The commonly used Weibull and exponential distributions are its limiting cases and log logistic distribution is its particular case. The distribution has been found appropriate for modeling failures that occur with less frequency and also when there is high occurrence of early failures.
Park and Yum2 are the first to propose the optimum ALT plan under modified stress loading methods.

Bai et al.3 have proposed an optimum time-censored single-objective ramp test with stress upper bound for Weibull life distribution to overcome such a situation. Further, most of the previous work on planning ALT has focused on a sole estimating objective, such as some specified 100pth quantile lifetime, the reliability of a product over some specified period of time and accelerating factor. It is impractical to estimate only one objective parameter after conducting such costly tests. Optimum constant-stress ALT plans with multiple estimating objectives have been designed by Xu and Fei.4

Since in practicing ALT one is interested in lower tail of the life distribution therefore, a single-objective optimal plan would separately minimize asymptotic variance of Maximum Likelihood Estimate (MLE) of log of quantiles 1%, 10% and 50%. It is impractical to obtain an optimal plan using a single-objective as done in the literature after conducting such costly tests. Therefore, a multi-objective plan has been considered in this article, which can easily be reduced to a single-objective plan by taking relevant weight equal to one and the rest of them equal to zero.

Many life distribution models have been used in the literature to analyze ALT data such as exponential distribution, normal distribution, Weibull distribution, log normal distribution, extreme value distribution, logistic distribution, log logistic distribution and truncated logistic distribution. The need to analyze ALT data with so many life distribution models is necessitated since the use of correct life distribution model, especially in the presence of a limited source of data (as typically occurs with modern devices) having high reliability, helps in preventing the choice of unnecessary and expensive planned replacements.

In this article, we have obtained an optimum time-censored multi-objective modified constant-stress ALT test plan for Burr type-XII life distribution. The Burr type-XII life distribution has a non-monotone hazard function, which can accommodate many shapes of hazard function. It has algebraic tails, which are effective for modeling failures that occur with less frequency than in corresponding models based on exponential tails. The Weibull and exponential life distributions are special limiting cases of its parametric values of this distribution and log-logistic distribution is a particular case of this distribution. This distribution has been found appropriate for accelerated life testing experiments. Accelerated life testing and repair time are examples of such situations (see Soliman5). As an example of a product lifetime distribution in which Burr distribution is more appropriate, Nelson6 (p.105) has given data on times to breakdown of an insulating fluid between electrodes at a voltage of 34 KV (minutes). Also, the times to breakdown are given. Zimmer et al.7 shows that the Burr type-XII model is acceptable for these data. Cook et al.8 has used the Burr model to obtain better fits to a uranium survey data set.

The article is organized as follows: maximum likelihood (ML) estimate of model parameters and their asymptotic covariance matrix are obtained. The optimum proportion of units allocated to different stress levels and optimum low stress level are found. The data analysis is presented just to validate the model (design) formulated. The method developed has been illustrated using an example. Confidence intervals involving design parameters have also been obtained and sensitivity analysis carried out. Finally the proposed model has been compared with the Park and Yum2 model using the simulated failure time data set. Using the same data set, the proposed multi-objective plan has been compared with a single-objective plan with respect to changes in the values of the parameters, equal weights and unequal weights.

Failed items are not replaced during the test.

The shape parameter “k” does not depend on the stress level.

At any constant stress s, the lifetime of a unit follows a Burr type-XII model with scale parameter
α ( s )
and shape parameters c and k, and the inverse power law holds for
α ( s )
assuming k is known for the sake of mathematical convenience.

sec.title: Inverse power law
sec.p: The inverse power law is used for analyzing data for which the accelerated stress is non-thermal in nature. It is frequently used as an accelerating stress for products such as capacitors, transformers and insulators.

Suppose that the accelerating stress variable
V
is positive. The inverse power law relationship between “nominal life”
ψ

sec.title: Cumulative exposure model
sec.p:
When the stress
s ( t )
is a function of time, and the life distribution for a failure mode depends on
s ( t )
only through a scale parameter
α ( s )

ε
for the failure mode is given by

and the population fraction failed by time t under
s ( t )

where G(.) is the assumed cumulative distribution with the scale parameter set equal to zero. This is a generalized formulation of the cumulative damage model, where stress can be any function of time, for example a ramp-stress, a monotonically increasing stress, sinusoidal, etc.
When s(t) is a linear function of t, we have a ramp-stress model.

sec.title: Burr type-XII lifetime distribution
sec.p: The Burr type-XII distribution has a non-monotone hazard function, which can accommodate many shapes of hazard function.
The probability density function (pdf), and cumulative distribution function (cdf), respectively, of Burr type-XII distribution are

where c and k are shape parameters and
α
is scale parameter. The Burr type-XII distribution is unimodal, and its mode is

and the pdf is L-shaped if
c ≤ 1 .
The reliability function and hazard function are given, respectively by

The Weibull life distribution tends to Burr type-XII distribution as
k → ∞

(see Appendix 2). The exponential life distribution also tends to Burr type-XII distribution as
k → ∞

k

and
c = 1
(see Appendix 3), and log-logistic distribution is a particular case of this distribution, as for k = 1, the distribution reduces to log-logistic distribution.
Literature5,10,11,12 discusses the statistical and probabilistic properties of the Burr type-XII distribution and its relationship to other distributions used in reliability analysis.

sec.title: Formulation of a multi-objective optimization problem
sec.p: A variety of approaches can be used to solve the multi-objective optimization problem. One popular approach is to combine these objectives into one single composite objective so that the traditional mathematical programming methods can be applied (see Liao and Li14). The latter approach is used in this article for the proposed plan.

A modified constant-stress test is specified by stress rate
β
. The
s
1
and
π
are determined by minimizing the weighted sum of asymptotic variances of ML estimators of quantile lifetimes at design constant stress. The asymptotic variance of the estimator is a function of

In practicing ALT, one is interested in the lower tails of the life distribution, i.e. early failures so 1%, 10% and 50% quantiles need to be considered.
The weights are chosen according to needs of the plan designed.

sec.title: Sensitivity analysis
sec.p:
To use an optimum test plan, one needs estimates of the design parameters
γ
0
,
γ
1
and
c
. These estimates sometimes may significantly affect the values of the resulting decision variables; therefore, their incorrect choice may give a poor estimate of the quantile at design constant stress. Hence, it is important to conduct sensitivity analysis to evaluate the robustness of the resulting ALT plan.
The percentage deviations (PD) of the optimal settings are measured by

where
Z
*
is the setting obtained with the given design parameters, and
Z
* *
is the one obtained when the parameter is mis-specified. Table 3 shows the optimal test plans for various deviations from the design parameter estimates. The results show that the optimal setting of Z is robust to the small deviations from baseline parameter estimates.

sec.p: Park and Yum2 have proposed a modified constant-stress test for exponential life distribution. Comparison of this plan with the proposed plan is not possible as the two plans are based on two different lifetime distributions with different indexing parameters.
Sensitivity analysis has been done to examine the effect of planning values of unknown parameters on the optimum plan.

sec.title: Comparative study
sec.p: In this section, comparative study has been carried out to highlight the merits of the proposed plan. In Table 4, the proposed modified constant-stress ALT model has been compared with the one designed by Park and Yum2 in terms of likelihood functions using the simulated failure time data set under modified constant-stress ALT with type-I censoring given in Table 2. Table 5 depicts a comparison of a multi-objective plan and single-objective plans with respect to changes in values of the parameters and Table 6 shows the comparison of a multi-objective plan with equal weights and unequal weights.

caption.p: Comparative study of modified constant-stress ALT models.

sec.p: Table 4 shows that the proposed model performs better than the Park and Yum2 modified constant-stress ALT model existing in the literature for the given data set. Table 5 shows that the multi-objective plan yields a smaller variance as compared with the single-objective plan at 50% quantile. Table 6 shows that the multi-objective plan yields a smaller variance as compared with the single-objective plan when more weight is given to Asvar corresponding to quantile 1%, when more weight is given to Asvar corresponding to quantile 10% and next higher weight is given to Asvar corresponding to quantile 1%.

sec.title: Concluding remarks
sec.p: In this article, an optimum time-censored multi-objective modified constant-stress ALT test plan for Burr type-XII life distribution has been obtained. The Burr type-XII life distribution model can be widely and effectively used in reliability applications because it has many different forms of reliability function and hazard function. The procedure developed has been explained using an example. Sensitivity analysis has been carried out. The result of sensitivity analysis shows that the optimum plan is robust for small deviations in the true values of the model parameters. A comparative study has also been carried out.

app.title: Appendix 5
app.p: Calculations of derivatives of the log-likelihood and the elements of the Fisher information matrix given in ‘Parameter Estimation’ and ‘Fisher Information Matrix’, respectively, follows.
The likelihood equations are obtained by setting equations (17)–(19) to zero.

The parameter values that solve “these equations summed over all test units” are the ML estimates. As the system of likelihood equations has no closed form solution in
